review.review_text:
Wonderful!

So thankful to go with friends/family that had been here before. Nearly impossible to narrow down the menu. Everything ordered was unique and delicious.

Berma Superstar is a magical restaurant. everything on the menu sounded so enticing we had a hard time deciding what the order. Fermented tea leaf salad is exceptionally exciting to the palate and addictive, I have a feeling I'll be back. We arrived for a late lunch and got immediate seating. The neighborhood has plenty of charming shops to walk around after you're done eating! This is definitely a unique San Francisco experience!

Loved the Burmese Samosa(the don't miss dish).
Chicken with basil sauce was good too.
Little congested, but the place is worth it.
Fresh and happy food :)

Great!!! Be prepared to wait (we went on a Friday evening and waited over an hour) and maybe have some stores to browse nearbt while waiting to be called. Very packed place right next to other people. Extremely fast and good customer service. GREAT food- everything is true what others have said! Good experience overall and will return if back in San Fran!

This is one of the city’s favorite restaurants. It has a sister restaurant close by if you don’t get seats here. There is no reservation taken here so you have go there and wait in line which is kind of a pain. I’ve waited here for 2-3 hours few times. It’s a very small location with maybe 15 tables to the maximum. But once you get a seat, the food is delicious. It’s worth the wait. My favorite is their samosa soup. That is a mixture of a lot of things but tastes amazing! Their tea leaf salad is something different and good. Highly recommend these two.
Wow. Awesome food, timely and fairly priced. The tastes were truly authentic. My entire family including kids loved it. Well done and highly recommended.

Last meal for us in San Fransisco after a week full of gluttony. Recommendation from a friend and a intriguing menu with significant vegetarian options were all the incentives we needed to land up at the Burma Superstar on Clement Street.

We called in early to put our name on the waitlist (2 hours). A critical requirement on a Saturday evening. Reached at 9 pm and still had to wait for ~30 mins also cos we were a large party of 7 and people on Table 34 just refused to get up even after finishing their food.

Anyways, the hostess kindly squeezed us in into a table of 6 and we were grateful given the strong, cold SF winds blowing on the streets outside.

First up was the Vegetarian Samusa Soup. We ordered it more out of curiosity as we hadn’t ever heard of a Samosa in a soup. Warm and very soupy with pieces of veg samosas and falafels thrown in. Delicious!! Gotta get the recipe cos wife can’t argue with the health benefits of a soup!!

The Mango salad was a safe option and went further by being a notch or two better than safe. The Lettuce Cups were just as good as one has had anywhere else.

The Plathas were a bit of a dampener (being used to the similar roti canai variation) as they were quite oily.

We are half full before main course thanks to the Sumptuous Samusa Soup. Still the Fiery Vegetables with Tofu which they made it in a not so fiery style given we had kids in the party. Went very well with the Tan Poi - rice with cardamoms, raisins, etc. The Vegetable Curry Delux was more like a potato subzi with lots of ras (liquidy gravy sort of thing) and was probably the only dish we didn’t finish.

The great food was only surpassed by the staff’s ever smiling and super helpful attitude (even after 5 hours of super hectic service). 

A total superstar!!
Try the tea leaf salad, samusa or just anything else on the menu, its bound to be good. This is a small place, always crowded and lively with great food.

One of my favourite restaurants in the world. It's a small place, always crowded, always need to wait for a table, but food to die for. Starting with the tea leaf salad to all the Burmese curries, it's fabulous. Worth the wait!

Had been here in the month of January while touring San Fran. My co-sister had recommended this place and it was quite a place.
To start with we ordered their famous Vegetarian Samusas Soup.  It was made of pungent red onion slices and crunchy samusa bite along with the hot flavourful broth. It was super delicious and highly recommended, will definitely try making this at home ;). We enjoyed SuperStar Vegetarian noodles which was made of flat noodles, stir fried brocoli, some other seasonal veggies and garlic.
The kitchen was about to close and we couldn't order much.
Would love to go back here on our next visit.

Came to San Fran for a short trip, and this restaurant was recommended by my uber driver. Turned out that he was right, this place was beyond my expectation! 
Came for a Monday dinner, we arrived around 4:45pm, there were ppl waiting outside. Luckily, we got in quickly.
This was my first time trying Burmese food, so I was pretty curious about this unfamiliar cuisine. 
Tea leaf salad: sliced fresh romaine lettuce, fried crunchy yellow beans,onion pieces,sunflower seeds, peanuts ,diced tomato and green pepper; of course, can't miss the special sauce made of imported Burmese tea leave. after adding some lemon juice and tossed to combine, the salad was ready to eat. Have to say, it was really good! Love the combination of freshness and crunchiness, the sauce was light and tasty. So curious how they made it! 
Chicken samusas(3p): this dishes was influenced by Indian cuisine. They filled with curry potato, chicken meat and some spices, tasted just like normal good quality samusas, but with visible large pieces of chicken meat! 
Chili lamb: thinly cut pieces of lamb meat stir fried with dry chillies, onion and basil. This dish was has strong cumin spice in it and little bit hot. The meat was perfect and sauce was tasty, however, it was too salt. It's better to have it with plain rice.
Pumpkin pork stew:it's a stew, not a curry dish. The pork meat was pretty lean and tender, so as the pumpkin(the flesh was dry, sweet,even kind of creamy to me, love it!) The sauce was very tasty yet not feel heavy at all! 
Nan Gyi Dok(coconut chicken rice noodle): round rice noodle with coconut curry sauce tossed together with chicken meat, egg, fried yellow beans and crispy wonton chips. The sauce was mild spicy, and creamy. Not bad! 
We finished the nice dinner with coconut pudding fritters with ice cream. The pudding was coated with batter and deep fried. Well, it was not amazing since I still felt little bit heavy. Also the ice cream was too sweet. 
Last but not least, you have to order some coconut rice! It was so~~~~~good! Rice was cooked very soft, tasted salty and sweet, very well balanced, and it was perfect to have with your main dishes! 
When you get the bill, you will like the restaurant even more! The value of the money was very good too! No wonder Burma superstar had such high review scores! If I have the chance, I will definitely go back for more yummy Burmese food!

If you have never tried Burmese food, then make sure your first time would be in Burma Superstar. The Burmese Curry was unbelievably amazing, I could eat it everyday. The spices paired with the perfectly cooked beef were a match made in curry heaven. And the coconut rice was so fragrant and flavorful. But the star of the show was the Tea Leaf Salad. I
am not a fan of salads, but this one was just impeccable. This place is definitely a superstar in my books.

I have never had Burmese food before this and I have missing out!  The food was sooo good and the staff was very kind.  On top of that they knew about food allergies and were helpful.  The portion sizes are good too.  My wife and I loved this place.  Recommend it highly!

I knew this place was popular so we made sure to get here 20 minutes before it opened for dinner on a thursday.  I'm glad we did as the line was about 20-30 people deep by the time doors opened.  We got seated and I was happy they served beer in larger sizes.  I got the 32 oz of Anchor Steam so I didn't need to worry about ordering extra later.

The fermented tea leaf salad was a must.  It was really unique in that the tea leaves gave a kind of tang that you wouldn't expect.  Plus they mix it at your table, that was kinda cool.  We also got the Burmese Samusas, and you can tell there is some Indian influence as there was a bit of curry that made them very interesting.  

The Steak Kabat was solid too.  A great mix of spicy and sweet with the tomatoes plus you could really pick out the mint, I know that might be a negative for some but I enjoyed.

The service was on point,  They got our food out really quickly but didn't feel rushed to get us out.  Burma Superstar is worthy of the hype.

Tea Leaf Salad (dish review). Tea Leaf Salad --- I hate tea with a fiery passion. I refuse to drink, look at, or be in the same room as the stuff. That said, I love Burma Superstar's signature Tea Leaf Salad, a delicious appetizer of Iceberg Lettuce (yuck), dried shrimp (yuck again), fried yellow beans (yum), garlic, sesame, jalapenos, tomatoes, and, of course, imported fermented tea leaves. The last of the aforementioned shopping list of ingredients that goes into each salad is easily the most special; each leaf comes hand-picked, hand-fermented, and hand-delivered from Burma itself. Though not everyone's cup of tea (kneeslapper), this salad's bombastic flavors meld together to create around 100 memorable bites. Nearly every texture - crunchy (beans), squishy (tomatoes), soft (tea leaves) - and flavor - spicy (jalapenos), smoky (sesame), bitter (tea leaves again) - can be picked out of the plate. It is essentially a work of art, a dish that earns its praise and deserves every good word said about it.

-----21 Aug, 2014-----
Braised Pork belly (dish review). Braised Pork Belly --- Pork belly (especially of the braised variety), is one of my favorite treats. Though it can be found smoked or grilled in the Americas and Europe, few continents cook it up quite like Asia does. Burma Superstar's superstar pork dish is a Chinese take on the classic protein, featuring a sweet garlic glaze and mustard greens. The meat itself is tender, coated in spice and sesame, and cut to highlight the succulent layer of fat that makes pork belly the world's worst for your waistline. This dish is made better by its price (a reasonable $17) and its size (one plate can serve as a main course for two), but it can surely rest on taste alone.

-----21 Aug, 2014-----
Burma Superstar (Burmese/Asian). Burma Superstar, San Francisco's bastion of Southeast Asian cuisine that ends in "-ese" yet doesn't start with "Viet", is one of my new favorites in The City. This star of Clement Street's little-known Chinatown serves up some delicious dishes made with only the freshest ingredients. Highlighting the pretty short, yet diverse menu is the Burmese Lamb Curry, a bowl of succulent, meaty morsels topped with spices, curry powder, and roasted potatoes. A second favorite is the Braised Pork Belly (actually a Chinese dish), a platter of crispy and fatty meat cooked in five spice and natural juices. Aside from the food, the service and atmosphere are both fairly spectacular, with knowledgeable staff and varying displays of Burmese art. Parking is easier on Mars, but you already knew that (SF is SF, after all). Wait times can range from one to two hours long (with lines that stretch for blocks), so be sure to arrive early and ready to order. Line length aside, Burma Superstar stands out in a city known for excellent ethnic fare; if you're in the Richmond District, few places around are better.

Rating: 8.8/10

Food is not really authentic but made to resemble of it. I felt like I drank a quart of Castrol motor oil my stomach was not agreeing at all. Some dishes may hit the spot and some may not it's hit or miss here.

Brought a friend's 9-year old daughter here. We waited about 15 minutes out front for a late Saturday lunch. The waiter gently teased her: she lapped it up. Gotta put in another vote for the tea leaf salad - the tastiest in the City.

Yes, the Tea Leaf Salad.. The tea leaf salad, noted on the menu "featured on Food Network", was super freakin delicious. Yes yes yes believe the hype. The curry noodles with boiled eggs on, that one is really really the bomb.

Small things bothered me a very little bit. Seating is very crowded and we got a table that must have been one of the worst (right by the front door with cold wind), some items on menu way too spicy for me but not noted on the menu, and the server really showing that she was annoyed when we sent the spicy one back.

Food runners/table side servers here are amazing. These gentlemen have the table side French service down. Yes it's a bit dumpy but the service of these guys are top notch.

Over all very pleasant experience. Will be back. About $25 per person before tip.

Excellent Dining Experience. Along with a friend, I had an excellent dining experience at Burma Superstar

There was a wait. But, we just grabbed a couple of drinks at Bitter End and circled back.

The service was very friendly and helpful. They really seemed to want to insure we had an enjoyable dining experience.

My friend had been there before. After we discussed the menu, she did the ordering and we shared everything.

She selected the following dishes:

Vegetable Samosas
Calamari
Tea Leaf Salad
Garlic Chili Shrimp
Spicy Chicken with Basil
Sesame Beef

I am going to simply divide the food into Excellent and Very Good. We enjoyed each dish.

Excellent:
Calamari
Tea Leaf Salad
Garlic Chili Shrimp

Very Good:
Vegetable Samosas
Spicy Chicken w Basil
Sesame Beef

Overall, this was a wonderful dining experience. The food combined with the friendly and warm service combined together for a near perfect meal.

Forkin Great. I've noticed that when I go to a place that has really excellent food, the staff is also great even when they're packed with people and a lesser restaurant would f*** up. This restaurant is ultra good, got the samusas and the beef kebat. Super fresh ingredients, the beef in the kebat was tender and perfectly cooked with the spiciness and heat I love. I could eat here every week and be very happy. Don't forget the free tea at the front door.
My favorite restaurant in sf. I crave the samosa soup and firey chicken & tofu constantly

Heaven on Earth. Tea Leaf Salad, Samusa soup, any of their curries, lettuce cups--all of it is amazing!! Similar but distinct to many of the surrounding regions' cuisine. The service is friendly and attentive. I could eat here every day of the week--made my family wish we could find a Burmese a cook if we were able to gain such a luxury.

Wonderful, great blend of Thai , Burmese and indian. Loved the Somosa soup, tea leaf salad, spicy chicken salad, spicy garlic shrimp. Soooo good. Hit the spot. There were four of us and we split all these entrees and had plenty of food!
Best Chinese food I've eaten in awhile. Had 3 different salads and spicy chicken and shrimp. also soup. Great food. Hard to find parking especially on Sunday, but food well worth it.

The Real Deal. Burma Superstar is the real deal. If you don't try the let phet thoke (ask for it "old man style"), you are missing out! Their mohingar hits the spot, too. One time, I peaked into the kitchen and saw the magic happening. Couldn't be more authentic.

Worth going to once at least!. The vegetarian samusa soup was really yummy - I would definitely have it again. The tea salad had a very unique flavour, which really grew on me. Definitely worth trying.

Oh, and the coconut mango drink was like mango lassi, but coconut-y! Awesomeness.

The maitre d' guy was really nice, as were all the servers. I'm not sure I'd have waited an hour (especially when their sister restaurant, B-Star, is just down the street and serves all the most popular dishes), but we waited 15-20 minutes and it was definitely worth it.
Once I land at SFO, my first stop is here. Worth the wait.

AMAZING AMAZING!!!. The food here is amazing and well worth the long wait! take this from someone who knows how burmese food should taste. tea leaf salad, moh hinga, on noh kauser, superstar noodles!!! everytime i visit san francisco this is a must stop...only wish they had one in seattle. come open one in seattle pls!
Tea salad always pleases. Had the pork and pumpkin curry which was mild with lots of roasted pumpkin. Coconut pudding fritters are a great way to end the meal. Great service and good food.

Wonderful Find. After visiting the Golden Gate Park and walking the GG bridge I was ready for lunch. Using the Urbanspoon app on my iphone I was off to the Richmond district for Burmese food. What a treat. I was able to slip in between lunch waves. What a menu...so many options...I ordered their Rainbow salad (the menu mentioned it had been featured on FoodTV, and a local program) along with the potato & chicken samosa. Divine. Flavorful. Fresh. Pleasant staff. Cute neighborhood. Worth a walk around and visit to Asian markets, cute coffee shops, etc in the area.

I am hooked!. After waiting for an hour and a half you better think the place has to be awesome. Yes, you are absolutely right. It rocks! Samosa soup and the tea leaf salad are superlative. Its brilliant. Its soo evil. So its one of those places you wanna visit just on the pretext of indulging yourself.

I am already plotting my return for the delicious tea leaf salad.... I am hooked.

Bad service bad food. The wait to get in is unbelievable, the time to get your food long, and then when you finally do get your food you really wished you hadn't wasted all that time.  We went once and vowed never again.

Yummy...but always crowded. Interesting flavors & spices...different from other sorts of Asian food offered on Clement. This place is always packed....so I like to call in my order and eat at home. There is one type of rice they serve that is sooo yummy, but can't recall what they call it.  Also try BStar a block down...less crowded, they have a heated back patio which is nice - and I believe a full bar. :)
